Generalplan Ost - Eastern Integration: Final Phase

The challenges posed by Generalplan Ost were monumental and would challenge every aspect of the Reich's capabilities. Enormous amounts of industrial output, raw material, manpower, financial investment, partisan suppression and much more were required for Germany to begin consolidating its conquests in the former territories of the USSR.\n \nSeveral years have passed since we first began Generalplan Ost, and it seems like a lifetime ago that administration of the eastern conquests may have stressed the Reich's resources to their breaking point. Nevertheless, through your leadership and careful management, we have overcome these challenges and our eastern territories can now finally support themselves. New German villages will one day turn into cities, while brand new railroads and autobahns stretch across the vast landscapes of the east. There is still much to be done, particularly in our designated colonization zones, but the most difficult phase of Generalplan Ost is now over.
A small price to pay for our thousand year Reich.
Fate of Mongolia

After our final invasion of the USSR, Mongolia came under our control. Once a puppet state under the control of the Soviets, the Mongolian people and its territory is of no interest to the Reich. If we are allied with Japan, we can transfer control of the area to them. Otherwise, we can reinstate a Mongolian government friendly to the Reich, or transfer control of the territory to Nationalist China.
Create a Mongolian government friendly to our interests.
Cede Mongolia to China.
Cede Mongolia to Japan.
Continue the occupation of Mongolia.
Fate of East Turkestan

After our final invasion of the USSR, East Turkestan came under our control. Once a puppet state under the control of the Soviets, the people and territory of East Turkestan is of no interest to the Reich. If we are allied with Japan, we can transfer control of the area to them. Otherwise, we can reinstate a Chinese government friendly to the Reich, or transfer control of the territory to Nationalist China.
Create a Chinese government friendly to our interests.
Cede East Turkestan to China.
Cede East Turkestan to Japan.
Continue the occupation of East Turkestan.
Transformation of the East

The greatest mission that the German nation has ever undertaken has finally been accomplished. After years of settling volksdeutsche into the eastern territories, we have finally achieved control of the frontier. Our Reichskommissariats have accomplished their task and are now fully exploiting the bountiful resources of what was once European Russia.
 
No longer will the natives cause us any disruption in building our vision of the ideal civilization. Our targeted zones of colonization are flourishing, with new farmsteads and large families dotting the landscape that we seized from the Asiatic menace.
 
By right of conquest, we claimed this land. By the capable hands and unshakeable will of the Aryan volk, we have transformed it into a bastion of the Reich. Over the course of centuries, these lands will become as German as Berlin. Congratulations - Generalplan Ost has been a decisive success!
To last a thousand years.
Division of Power

On December 15, 1941 the Japanese proposed to Germany a division of the respective spheres of influence on the Asian continent. This proposal delimited a territorial arrangement with a division along the 70th meridian east longitude. The Germans were initially apprehensive about this proposal, fearing that it established an unwelcome precedent for future partitions of political entities along this dividing line, and that it failed to contain any promise of Japanese military support against the USSR.
 
The Wehrmacht further criticized this proposal because it arbitrarily cut through existing states with no concern or attention given to natural geographical features or economical concerns that made the existence of these entities possible. They counterproposed a division that would follow existing state boundaries, which ran along the eastern border of Iran, northern Afghanistan, the western border of China and then along the Yenisei River.
 
Historically, Hitler approved the Japanese proposal. This was likely because he did not believe that Germany would realistically ever gain Soviet territory beyond the Ural Mountains.
The New Order has been formalized.
Arkhangelsk-Astrakhan line

The Arkhangelsk-Astrakhan line or "A-A line" was the military goal of Operation Barbarossa. It originated from an earlier military study by Erich Marcks called "Operation Draft East". The hypothetical A-A line was to stretch from the port city of Arkhangelsk on the White Sea along the confluence of the Volga river to the port city of Astrakhan on the Caspian. This study envisioned that the campaign would take between nine and seventeen weeks to complete.\n \nOperation Barbarossa was to intended to accomplish this objective before the onset of winter in 1941. This would result in the occupation of the vast majority of the Soviet Union's industrial, population, food and fuel centers and render it incapable of posing a threat to Germany after the war was concluded. The remaining Soviet industrial centers eastward in the Urals and beyond were to be destroyed by aerial bombardment.
Russia will never rise again.
Partition of Turkey

The state of Turkey in the Second World War was precariously balanced between all three major factions - the Germans briefly examined both Turkish cooperation and occupation, and Italian ambitions in the Mediterranean came dangerously close to Turkish borders. The British were well aware that Turkey straddled the gateway between Europe and the Middle East and could be used as an avenue to strike into Syria. Finally, the Soviet Union with its historical Russian antagonism towards the Ottoman Empire did not let any of these concerns go unnoticed, and knew that their possessions in the Caucasus could come under threat if Turkey were to find itself aligned towards the Germans.\n \nDuring the course of the war, Turkey came under our occupation. We must now decide the fate of this region. Anatolia is a diverse area full of national groups with various interests, many of them that have been under centuries of occupation. We must balance these groups with own interests in the area, the ambitions of our allies, and of course the future of the Turkish nation itself. It is time to continue drawing the map of the New Order.
Let's get started. Go through each area one by one.
There will be no partition. Create the Turkish State.
Expand RK Kaukasus and create the Turkish State.
Restore the Ottoman Empire. This region needs stability.
Expand RK Kaukasus and restore the Ottoman Empire.
Partition of Turkey - Thrace

The region of Thrace has competing interests among the Bulgarian, Turkish and Greek nations. This area has been a hotspot of conflict between these groups in the past, and these old tensions have risen again after our occupation.\n \nIn 1453, the Ottoman Empire conquered the city of Constantinople and forever altered the course of history. Now that we have occupied this historic city and the surrounding area, we hold the future in our hands. We have many options for how to partition Thrace, and should examine each possibility carefully.
Cede Thrace to Bulgaria and we will occupy Istanbul.
Cede Thrace to Bulgaria and return Istanbul to Turkey.
Occupy all of Thrace to ensure this area remains stable.
Turkey will regain Thrace, but we will occupy Istanbul.
Turkey will regain all of Thrace.
Partition of Turkey - Cyprus

Cyprus has been a critical stronghold in the eastern Mediterranean since man first set sail upon its waters. Consisting mostly of ethnic Greeks, this island has an ancient history and still serves as an important strategic location in this area.\n \nNow that we have expelled the British from the island, we need to decide on its future ownership. Note that this area is specifically noted in the Italian sphere of interest, and it would upset them if they were not granted this concession.
The Italians have the strongest claim here.
We need this island for our interests in the Mediterranean.
Create an autonomous Cypriot state.
Partition of Turkey - Reichskommissariat Kaukasus

The administrative division of Reichskommissariat Kaukasus is primarily intended to protect our interests in the region's oil fields, most notably Baku. Control of this region is critical to the survival and future prosperity of the Third Reich.
 
It may be wise to expand a buffer zone into eastern Anatolia and northern Persia to ensure that Baku is shielded from any future conflicts that might happen in the area. German administration of the varied nationalities in these areas under one consolidated rule would better ensure that we will have better control over them. It would be unwise for us to allow Turkish or Armenian nationalists to interfere with our vision.
 
We will still have the chance to examine the possibility of autonomy for these local nationalities in the area regardless of our decision.
Expand RK Kaukasus into eastern Anatolia.
Expand RK Kaukasus into eastern Anatolia and northern Persia.
This is unnecessary. Proceed with the next area.
Partition of Turkey - Armenia

The establishment of Reichskommissariat Kaukasus took into consideration the presence of various national groups in the area, most notably the Armenians, Georgians, and Azeri people. Now that our control in this area is complete, we can decide on the nature of our governance for these nations. Our interests in Baku are too critical to yet grant any form of independence to the Azeri people.\n \nHitler believed that these traditionally warring groups would need to be subjected to a strict level of control, but that they would not be subjected to the forced labor and enslavement that the Slavic peoples in nearby areas were to be used for. The discussion between himself, Alfred Rosenberg and other minds of the party never reached a consensus on the best form of management for this area. Examine these options carefully. We need to decide if creating independent states such as Armenia would best serve our interests, or if keeping them contained within the Reichskommissariat will ultimately be the best choice.
Create Greater Armenia.
Create Greater Armenia and create Georgia as well.
Only release Armenia and Georgia, do not take Turkish territory.
No autonomy. The Reichskommissariat will not be compromised.
Partition of Turkey - Kurdistan

Our occupation of both Turkey and Persia did not go unnoticed by the Kurdish people, who have sent nationalist leaders to petition us for a state of their own. While this new entity could serve as a useful measure in the typical strategy of divide and conquer, the Kurds are located in an area that has made their independence historically difficult.\n \nStraddled between the Arabic-speaking peoples of the Middle East, the Persians and the Turks, the Iranic tribe of the Kurds has struggled for their sovereignty throughout the centuries. These nationalist leaders would be forever indebted to us if we were to grant them their own state, but we must decide if they are worthy of this concession and if it will best serve our interests in the Middle East.
The time has come to put Kurdistan on the map.
An independent Kurdistan is not in our interests.
Partition of Turkey - Final Step

Now that all of the contested areas have had their partitions decided upon, we need to focus on the Turkish nation itself. We may establish a new Turkish State in central Anatolia, and will closely monitor their affairs to ensure that a new conflict will not break out in the region. With time, these borders will become the accepted New Order that we have created.
Finish the partition and create the Turkish State.
Turkey will remain occupied.
The Swedish Question

Sweden found itself in a tenuous position during the events of the Second World War. Having maintained its neutrality since the end of Napoleonic Wars in 1815, it was only through a careful balance of diplomatic maneuvering and concessions to Germany that Sweden was able to maintain its sovereignty and avoid direct involvement in the conflict. During Operation Barbarossa, Sweden allowed the Wehrmacht railway transit for personnel and munitions into Finland. The country was also a vital trading partner that supplied critical iron ore to the Reich. As the war neared its conclusion in 1944 and 1945, they allowed the Allies to use Swedish air bases. Sweden also became an important destination for refugees fleeing the war, including Jewish and other persecuted populations.\n \nHitler's personal of view of the Swedish was generally positive, as he viewed the Scandinavian people to be of the purest Nordic descent. Sweden was not occupied during the war for a variety of reasons, not least of which was that occupation would have been costly and that the Swedes were generally compliant with the Reich's interests. With the conclusion of the war against the Soviet Union, their incorporation into the Greater Germanic Reich can now be accomplished. It is time to unite all Germanic people under our banner!
Demand their incorporation into the Reich!
Just propose a military alliance.
This is unnecessary - allow Sweden to remain neutral.
Germany demands our submission
With the war in Europe concluded, the Germans have turned their eye towards us. They are demanding our submission to the New Order!
We accept an alliance with the Reich.
We reject the Reich's proposal for an alliance.
We have no choice. Stand down.
Never! We will resist this madness!
Sweden has accepted our proposal
The Swedish have seen reason and accepted our proposal. All of Scandinavia is now within our sphere of influence.
The Swedish are natural allies of the Reich.
The Swedish a vital component of the New Order.
Sweden has rejected our proposal

The Swedish have foolishly rejected our demands! Despite being surrounded on all sides and having no hope of resisting us, they have declared that they will make a last stand to protect their sovereignty, if necessary.
We tried to be reasonable, now they have forced our hand.
They will become part of the Reich, willingly or not.
This isn't worth going to war over. Let it go.
Fate of Scandinavia

The Reichskommissariats in western Europe differed considerably from their eastern counterparts. The regimes set up in Belgium and the Netherlands were intended to factilitate a transitional incorporation into the Reich, in contrast to the Russian conquests which focused on colonization and exploitation. Historically, a Reichskommissariat division did not encompass all of Scandinavia, though the regime established in Norway serves as an example for this concept. Hitler vowed that he would never leave Norway, and even favored the annexation of Denmark at a later date. The Nordic people of Scandinavia were destined to become part of the Reich once Hitler's vision came to fruition.\n \nNow that we have brought all of Scandinavia under our control, we can create a new Reichskommissariat to ensure that this area will become an integral part of the German nation. Its population will retain their native languages and customs for a time, while the next generation will be educated to identify solely with their Germanic racial character and no longer see themselves as part of disparate nationalities. They will be taught to celebrate their Aryan heritage and embrace National Socialist ideology. With time, the Greater Germanic Reich will be one people and one nation!
Create Reichskommissariat Scandinavia!
Directly annex Scandinavia into the Reich!
Create friendly regimes in Scandinavia instead.
No need. Restore Sweden and maintain the status quo.
No need. Maintain the status quo.
The Celtic Congress

The New Order in Europe is seeing a fascinating revival of many of her ancient institutions and practices. Through our guidance, the nations of Ireland, Scotland, Wales and Britanny have found themselves united and on the map once again. They have been allowed to conduct a Celtic Congress to celebrate their shared national identity.\n \nGerman National Socialism generally viewed these people as one of the last few remaining traces of pure European heritage, which should be celebrated and protected. Under our watchful eye, these nations are finding themselves surging with the pride of their ancestors once again.
A new dawn of neo-paganism will purify Europa!
German language schooling

A key tenant of National Socialist ideology was the education of the next generation. A highly regimented program of raising young Germans was put into place in National Socialist Germany with a strong emphasis on physical activities, martial trianing and identity with the German nation and state.
 
Now that we are the new masters of Europe, we are installing a program of German language schooling throughout the various nations. The language that one speaks has a profound influence on his or her identity and their ability to express themselves. If one thinks and speaks in German, it is a critical step to eventually becoming German themselves if they are racially worthy. If this is combined with carefully planned population settlement and state-sponsored programs to support large families, the German nation will skyrocket and make full use of the Lebensraum in the east.
 
With time, patience and dilgence, German will become the new dominant language and its people the undisputed masters of Europe.
He alone, who owns the youth, gains the future.
French fascism takes root

As the new regime in France becomes more accepted by its population, the ideas of French fascism are taking hold. One of the most unique aspects of fascist ideology is the unique character that it takes based upon the national character of the people that it finds itself manifested within.
 
Within the French State, legendary figures such as Joan of Arc and the Gaulish chieftan Vercingetorix are seeing a resurgance in popular art and literature. Cultural icons such as these serve as the foundation for the identity of the French nation. Petain frequently addresses his people via radio broadcast, celebrating the destruction of the Third Republic and its excessive, degenerate nature. Only through a period of purifying French society could the dangerous ills wrought by the old ideals of liberty, equality and fraternie be cured.
 
Despite suffering from the peace terms imposed by them by the Germans, a sense of Anglophobia is even more dominant among the French, placing the blame squarely upon them for dragging France into such a terrible war that saw the end of their sovereignity as a state. However, many are now seeing this as not a disaster at all, but rather a blessing that the guiding hand of National Socialism has pulled them out of the darkness of liberal ideologies and into the strength and unity of a coherent, vital nation that is so critical to the future of the French State and French nation.
We must undo the damage done by the French Revolution.
Mitteleuropa

The concept of "Mitteleuropa" was first known to have been theorized in 1848 by Karl Ludwig von Bruck and Lorenz von Stein. This notably German concept envisioned a united customs and market bloc of European nations with the goal of facilitating trade between these states. The term "Mitteleuropa" has gained various connotations from this first formulation.
 
In 1915, German thinker Friedrich Naumann wrote about the realization of the Mitteleuropa concept as a way to achieve Prussian economic and cultural hegemony over Europe through the eventual domination of the German Empire. This would be achieved by establishing a number of satellite states who would serve as markets for the German economy and allow it to better compete with powers such as Britain and France. This was seen as a severe threat by the British Empire, who took close notice of these ambitions and how it might affect their own markets.
 
With our growing domination of Europe, vestiges of the Mitteleuropa concept are manifesting themselves. Although National Socialist ideology promotes independence from foreign trade and an eventual goal of national autarky, the exploited resources from our conquests in the east along with vital trading partners such as Portugal and Romania are ensuring that our economy is running smoothly. With time and consolidation, Germany will be the undisputed military, economic and cultural masters of Europe.
None can make use of Europe's resources better than us.
Leon Degrelle's ambitions

Leon Degrelle was the founder of Belgian Rexist Party, which advocated for a moral renewal of Belgian society that would be accomplished through the Catholic Church. This was modeled similarly to Italian fascism in that advocated for a corporatist organization of society and denounced the ideologies of liberal democracy as having a degenerating influence on the Belgian nation. In 1936, Leon met both Mussolini and Hitler, whom provided 2 million lire and 100,000 marks respectively to show their support for Rexism.
 
When the war began, Degrelle approved of King Leopold III's neutrality, but soon found the Rexist party split upon the German invasion. He was accused of collaboration, arrested, and evacuated to France. After the occupation of France began, he was released and then returned to Belgium to reconstruct his own vision of Rexism in close union with National Socialism. He joined the Waffen-SS as the leader of the 28th SS Volunteer Grenadier Division Wallonien and served on the eastern front during Operation Barbarossa.
 
Degrelle was one of the most outspoken candidates of the concept of the resurrected Burgundian state, and it was assumed that he would become the first chancellor of this new German entity. His vision was to restore the domain of Charles the Bold before his death in 1477 under his own rule. Now that the Burgundian state has come into being, Leon has asked us to merge the regime in Belgium into the SS-Ordensstaat to see this dream become a reality.
Allow Leon to see his dream realized - under our control.
No - one must not allow their vassals to become too strong.
Germany responds to our request
Germany has responded to our request to merge the Reichskommissariat in Belgium with our realm.
The Kingdom of Burgundy is reborn under the Third Reich!
Disappointing, but we have no choice but to accept.

The Fall of France

The surrender of the French Third Republic to the Third Reich stunned the world - France, still seen as the strongest military power in Europe and arguably throughout the world, was not expected to capitulate in the summer of 1940. Even the German General Staff had serious doubts about the viability of the campaign. As noted by Franz Halder on November 3, 1939 - "None of the higher headquarters think that the offensive has any prospect of success." Hitler's proposal carried an enormous risk that could have resulted in a catastrophic defeat for the nascent Reich.
 
Not only did the Allies possess overall more tanks than the Germans in the spring of 1940, the British and French models were superior. In addition to this, the Allies had captured a draft of the initial invasion plans when a German plane crashed over Belgium in January 1940. Erich von Manstein, supported by Heinz Guderian and Gerd von Rundstedt, instead proposed an alternative plan - a "sickle cut" maneuver through the Ardennes forest directly into France around Sedan. This plan was phenomenally risky, as it was a 300 kilometer race to the coast with no supporting infantry and had the potential to completely cut off the advancing Panzer divisions. The plan was successful and the Allies were caught completely off-guard, resulting in a decisive military victory for the Germans.
 
Where the Deutsches Heer had not been able to achieve success in the 4 years of the First World War, the Wehrmacht was able to conquer France in a matter of weeks. The world was left stunned, and the British now stood alone.

The arriving French delegation immediately recognized Hitler's objective of a symbolic humiliation and revenge for the Treaty of Versailles.

The Alsace-Lorraine Monument (depicting a German Eagle impaled by a sword) was destroyed and the site obliterated, aside from the statue of Ferdinand Foch. The carriage itself was taken to Berlin along with pieces of a stone tablet that had the following inscribed in French: HERE ON THE ELEVENTH OF NOVEMBER 1918 SUCCUMBED THE CRIMINAL PRIDE OF THE GERMAN REICH. Beyond these considerable defenses, the British were prepared to use even more extensive strategies to stop an invasion. Planned destruction of bridges, slash and burn tactics of both food and fuel, full mobilization of the civilian population, insurgency networks and even poison gas attacks were to be used in the defense of the home islands.

Oswald Mosley's reforms

Oswald Mosley was a pioneer of fascist ideology, representing the genesis of the unique character of British fascism. He believed that state ownership and market capitalism had both failed, and supported a new system of "industrial democracy" in which employees would become stakeholders in their companies. By instituting this system of labor, he believed it would promote greater incentives in the workforce since their share of the profits would depend directly on their own ability and initiative.
 
Mosley also believed in the abolishment of the income tax, a drastic reform of central banking, and a New Model parliament that would operate on the fundamental ideology of a technocracy - experts within their respective fields of industry would nominate leaders from within their own vocations, ensuring those most suited for the job would be selected.
 
Finally, he believed in outlawing the practice of designing products with built-in obsolescence, believing that this exploitation of the consumer was reprehensible and that products should be designed to last. Housing shortages and other critical needs for the British people must be addressed with the highest priority, and the the motto of "Britain First" encompassed his innovative ideology.

Schwerer Gustav and Dora

Schwerer Gustav was a German 80 cm railway gun developed in the late 1930s by Krupp. The gun was designed in preparation for the Battle of France, but was not ready for action when the battle began, and in any case the Wehrmacht's Blitzkrieg offensive through Belgium rapidly outflanked and isolated the Maginot Line's static defenses, eventually forcing the French to surrender and making their destruction unnecessary. Gustav was later deployed in the Soviet Union during the Battle of Sevastopol, part of Operation Barbarossa, where among other things, it destroyed a munitions depot buried in the bedrock under a bay. The gun was moved to Leningrad, and may have been intended to be used in the Warsaw Uprising like other German heavy siege pieces, but the rebellion was crushed before it could be prepared to fire. Gustav was destroyed by the Germans near the end of the war in 1945 to avoid capture by the Red Army. Dora was the second gun produced. It was deployed briefly against Stalingrad, where the gun arrived at its emplacement 15 kilometres to the west of the city sometime in mid-August 1942. It was ready to fire on 13 September. However, it was soon withdrawn when Soviet encirclement threatened.\n \nSchwerer Gustav and Dora were the largest-calibre rifled weapon ever used in combat and, in terms of overall weight, the heaviest mobile artillery piece ever built. It fired the heaviest shells of any artillery piece. It is surpassed in calibre only by the unused British Mallet's Mortar and the American Little David bomb-testing mortar.

Friedenthal and Sonderlehrgang z.b.V. Oranienburg. column2: Michael Wittmann

Michael Wittmann, born on 22 April 1914, in Vogelthal, joined the German Army in 1934. Discharged as a corporal in September 1936, the ambitious young man then joined the Waffen SS in April 1937 and was assigned to the elite Leibstandarte SS Adolf Hitler (LSSAH). During the brief Polish campaign and then in the German blitzkrieg sweep into Belgium, Holland, and France, he commanded a six-wheeled heavy armored car on reconnaissance sorties. 
 When Nazi armies swarmed across the Russian border on June 22, 1941, the LSSAH panzers rolled southward and Wittmann quickly distinguished himself as a tank commander in the first of many clashes with the Red Army.In less than a year of action on the Eastern Front, Wittmann was credited with 66 tank kills. Wittmann was awarded the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves on 30 January 1944 for the destruction of 117 tanks, making him the 380th member of the German armed forces to receive it. Wittmann received the award from Adolf Hitler personally at the Wolf's Lair, Hitler's headquarters in Rastenburg, on 2 February 1944. On 7 June, following the Allied Invasion of Normandy, the battalion was ordered to move to Normandy, where Wittmann became known for the Battle of Villers-Bocage on 13 June 1944. While in command of a Tiger I tank, he destroyed up to fourteen tanks and fifteen personnel carriers, along with two anti-tank guns, within the space of fifteen minutes. The news was picked up and disseminated by the Nazi propaganda machine and added to Wittmann's stature in Germany.
 
On August 8th 1944, Wittmann died in a battle, when his Tiger tank was destroyed during an ambush near the French town of Saint-Aignan-de-Cramesnil. During his career, he recorded 138 tank kills, 132 anti-tank gun kills, and destroyed hundreds of trucks, carriers, artillery, and errant sportscars.
Dmitry Lavrinenko

Dmitry Fyodorovich Lavrinenko, born on September 10th 1914 was a Soviet tank commander and Hero of the Soviet Union. He was the highest scoring tank ace of the Allies during World War II. \n A descendant of Kuban Cossacks, Lavrinenko finished his training at Ulyanovsk Tank Academy in May 1938. He took part in Soviet campaigns in Poland in 1939 and Bessarabia in 1940. In 1941, he commanded the new T-34/76 tank. With 58 tanks and self-propelled guns eliminated in 1941 during Operation Barbarossa on the Eastern Front of World War II, he is considered to be one of the top Soviet tank aces of the war, despite his early death in 1941. He achieved such impressive results by taking advantage of the abilities of the T-34. The tank's armor and great mobility were clearly taken into consideration by Lavrinenko. On December 18, 1941 Lavrinenko was killed just after freeing the village of Goryuny and knocking out his 52nd tank. Immediately after the action the Germans began shelling the village intensively. Lavrinenko got out of his T-34 near the village and tried to reach the commander of the 17th Armoured Brigade, Lt Col N. Chernoyarov, in order to report his victory but he was killed by a German mortar shell fragment. \n The total number of tanks damaged and destroyed by Lavrinenko is comparatively small next to aces like Michael Wittmann (138 tanks and 132 anti-tank guns), Otto Carius (150 tanks), Kurt Knispel (168 tanks), and several others. However, almost all the German tank aces of the war fought from start to finish, so their overall results were more significant. Lavrinenko destroyed 52 tanks in just 2.5 months of fierce fighting in 1941. This was an outstanding result in the Soviet Army, and no single Allied tank officer surpassed him during the whole war.
Anniversary of Revolution

On this day in 1941, the 24th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, Joseph Stalin, premier and dictator of the USSR, delivered a speech to a rally of Moscow Party workers. The rally was held underground, in the marbled halls of the Mayakovsky train station. Amber Room

The Amber Room or Yantarnaya Komnata was a world-famous chamber decorated in amber panels backed with gold leaf and mirrors, located in the Catherine Palace of Tsarskoye Selo near Saint Petersburg. Although it was originally created in early 18th century in Berlin, it was given by the Prussian King Frederick William I to his then ally, Tsar Peter the Great in 1716. In Russia, the room was expanded, and after several renovations, it covered more than 55 square metres and contained over 6 tonnes of amber. \nShortly after the beginning of the German invasion of the Soviet Union in World War II, the curators responsible for removing the art treasures in Leningrad tried to disassemble and remove the Amber Room. However, over the years the amber had dried out and become brittle, making it impossible to move the room without crumbling the amber.The Amber Room was therefore hidden behind mundane wallpaper, in an attempt to keep German forces from seizing it. Predictably, the attempt to hide such a well-known piece of art failed. German soldiers of Army Group North disassembled the Amber Room within 36 hours under the supervision of two experts. On 14 October 1941, the priceless room reached Königsberg in East Prussia, for storage and display in the town's castle. \nIn August 1944, Königsberg was heavily fire bombed by the Royal Air Force. It suffered further extensive damage from artillery from the advancing Red Army before the final occupation on 9 April 1945. Its current whereabouts remain a mystery, but it is highly believed that the room was destroyed during these raids.
The road of life

By 8 September 1941, the German Army Group North under Feldmarschall Wilhelm Ritter von Leeb had almost completely surrounded Leningrad, successfully cutting off all major supply routes. To address this growing concern, a decision was cast by the Military Soviet of the Leningrad Front to establish an evacuation commission in November 1941. As the severity of the siege intensified, the committee proposed the construction of an ice road over Lake Ladoga as both a viable supply line and means for civilian evacuation en masse. The Road of Life began to operate on 19 November 1941 after Captain Mikhail Murov and his transport regiment carried the first supplies over Lake Ladoga via horse-drawn sleigh. However, due to proximal bombardments, ice breakage, and unreliable machinery, the route was far from fully functional at this time. It was only in mid-December, after troops of the Volkhov front recaptured Tikhvin, that construction of a railroad directly connecting the western shore of Lake Ladoga to Leningrad was possible. \n The siege lasted for 29 months from 8 September 1941, to 27 January 1944. Over one million citizens of Leningrad died from starvation, stress, exposure and bombardments. Each winter, the Lake Ladoga ice route was reconstructed by hand, and built according to precise arithmetic calculations depending on traffic volume. In addition to transporting thousands of tons of munitions and food supplies each year, the Road of Life also served as the primary evacuation route for the millions of Soviets trapped within the starving city.
Arado Ar 234

As the German Messerschmitt Me 262 Schwalbe holds the distinction of becoming the world's first operational jet-powered fighter, the Arado Ar 234 Blitz is recognized as the world's first operational jet-powered bomber. The system arrived in 1944 and became active into 1945, serving until the end of war in 1945. It proved one of the more technologically advanced and prized weapons of the German Luftwaffe but was never available in the numbers required. The aircraft proved so advanced, in fact, that it was able to evade all available Allied interceptors of the time, making it a very capable reconnaissance and high-speed bombing platform. Unfortunately for the Germans, related testing and manufacture facilities were disrupted consistently, fuel supplies restricted and factories ultimately overrun by advancing Allied fronts limiting production to a few hundred examples by war's end. The West seemingly benefitted the most from the captured technology, the Americans in particular designing, developing and producing several jet-powered bombers of the Cold War that superficially resembled the wartime Ar 234 series to an extent (though frequently on a much larger scale). The Ar 234 became the German Luftwaffe's second jet-powered aircraft to enter service following the more recognizable Me 262.
Junkers Ju 87 'Stuka'

Before the Allies would gain air superiority over the skies of France and Germany, the Junkers Ju 87 'StuKa' dive bomber would reign supreme. The system, for a time, became the terror of both civilian and soldier alike, as the screaming howl of its 'Jericho Trumpet' sirens filled the sky with a shriek before letting lose with the aircraft's payload. In essence, the dive bomber was, for the first time, being used to critical effect - an almost forecasting of the capabilities of today's direct-strike precision bombing. The name 'StuKa' comes from the longform 'Sturzkampfflugzeug' which translates to 'Drop-Down-Fight-Airplane'. Once World War 2 had begun in September of 1939, the Stuka was a featured set piece for the German Luftwaffe in its conquest of Poland. The system earned its deadly reputation early on due to its precision strike abilities. Following the collapse of the Polish defenses, and the fall of Norway, the Low Countries and France, it was also used in the Battle of Britain, but with limited sucess. \nIn an effort to shore up its limitations, the Ju 87D model was revealed and these were posted along the East Front and during the North African Campaign. The Ju 87G model came online as a dedicated 'tank buster' armed through twin 37mm cannons. This particular entry provided new life to the series and would later prove to be one of the most successful designs of the war.
Blocking Detachment

In the Red Army of the Soviet Union, the concept of barrier troops first arose in August 1918 with the formation of the 'blocking troops' or 'anti-retreat detachments'. The barrier troops were composed of personnel drawn from Cheka punitive detachments or from regular Red Army infantry regiments. The first use of the barrier troops by the Red Army occurred in the late summer and fall on the Eastern front during the Russian Civil War, when commander Mikhail Tukhachevsky was authorized to station blocking detachments behind unreliable Red Army infantry regiments in the 1st Red Army, with orders to shoot if they either deserted or retreated without permission. \nThe concept was re-introduced on a large scale during the Second World War. On June 27, 1941, in response to reports of unit disintegration in battle and desertion from the ranks in the Soviet Red Army, the 3rd Department of the USSR's Narkomat of Defense issued a directive creating mobile barrier forces composed of NKVD personnel to operate on roads, railways, forests, etc. for the purpose of catching 'deserters and suspicious persons'. On September 12, 1941, Joseph Stalin issued the Stavka Directive No. 1919 concerning the creation of barrier troops in rifle divisions of the Southwestern Front, to suppress panic retreats. Each Red Army division was to have an anti-retreat detachment equipped with transport totalling one company for each regiment. Their primary goal was to maintain strict military discipline and to prevent disintegration of the front line by any means, including the use of machine guns to indiscriminately shoot any personnel retreating without authorization.
IS-2 'Josef Stalin'

The Soviet Army need for ever-more formidable tracked firepower came to the forefront after losses of much territory to the invading Germans in the summer of 1941. The stout KV heavy tank series (KV-1 and KV-2) proved adequate but only an extent for they lacked the necessary battlefield mobility of the fabled T-34 medium tank series while utilizing similar weaponry. The KV-1 was more of a tank-killer with its F-34 76.2mm main gun. The KV-2 mounted a 152mm howitzer and was more of a fire support vehicle thank tank destroyer. The T-34, while an ever-evolving system, lacked the required firepower with its base 76.2mm main gun and armor protection was limited, particularly against the ranks of the newer German Panther and Tiger heavy tank series. As such, endeavors were undertaken by the Red Army to present newer and better systems to level the playing field. One such development therefore became IS series of heavy tanks - popularly known as the 'Josef Stalin' series - the most powerful tank to serve in the Red Army during all of World War 2. The IS family set the stage for Soviet tank development doctrine for decades to come.
Downfall of Walther von Brauchitsch

Walther von Brauchitsch was born into an aristocratic military family in 1881. The Brauchitsch family had a long tradition of military service, and like his forefathers, Brauchitsch was raised in the tradition of the Prussian officer corps. During World War I, he served on the western front and was awarded the Iron Cross 1st Class as well as the House Order of Hohenzollern. When the Commander-in-Chief of the Army, Werner von Fritsch, was accused of homosexuality, Hitler appointed Brauchitsch a colonel general and the new army chief, on the recommendation of the Army High Command on 4 February 1938. Even though Brauchitsch was in charge of operational affairs during the Polish and French campaigns, he had very little influence, as a whole, as to the war's progress. \nWhen Germany turned East and invaded the Soviet Union in June 1941, he played a key part, making modifications to the original plan. As the Battle of Moscow got under way, his health was starting to fail. Even so, he continued his work, as he was determined to take Moscow before the start of winter. The army's failure to take Moscow earned Hitler's enmity, and things worsened for him, as he suffered a heart attack in November. He was also informed that he had a malignant cardiac disease, most likely incurable. In the aftermath of the failure at Moscow, Brauchitsch was dismissed as Commander-in-Chief of the German Army and replaced by Adolf Hitler himself on 19 December. He was transferred to the Führerreserve, where he remained without assignment until the end of the war.

The region north of the Caucasus mountains was a production center for grain, cotton and heavy farm machinery while its two main oilfields produced about 10 percent of all Soviet oil. Lucy Spy Ring

Roessler, a German expatriate from Bavaria who fled to Geneva when Hitler came to power, was working as a publisher at the outbreak of World War II in Switzerland, producing anti-Fascist literature. Roessler was approached by two German officers, Fritz Thiele and Rudolph von Gersdorff, who were part of a conspiracy to overthrow Hitler, and had been known to Roessler in the 1930s through the Herrenklub. 
 
Thiele and Gersdorf wished him to act as a conduit for high level military information, to be available to him to make use of in the fight against Fascism. This they accomplished by the simple expedient of equipping Roessler with a radio and an Enigma machine, and designating him as a German military station. In this way they could openly transmit their information to him through normal channels. Roessler's first major contribution to Soviet intelligence came in May 1941 when he was able to deliver details of Operation Barbarossa, Germany's impending invasion of the Soviet Union. Following the invasion, in June 1941, Lucy was regarded as a VYRDO source, i.e. of the highest importance, and to be transmitted immediately. Over the next two years 'Lucy' was able to supply the Soviets with high grade military intelligence. During the autumn of 1942, 'Lucy' provided the Soviets with detailed information about Case Blue, the German operations against Stalingrad and the Caucasus. In the summer of 1943, the culmination of 'Lucy's' success came in transmitting the details of Germany's plans for Operation Zitadelle, a planned summer offensive against the Kursk salient, which became a strategic defeat for the German army. 
 
The Lucy spy ring came to an end in the summer of 1944 when the German members, who were also involved in other anti-Nazi activities, were arrested in the aftermath of the failed July plot.
Reorganization of Soviet Airforce

When Nazi Germany attacked the Soviet Union in June 1941, it quickly became apparent that the Soviet Air Force was not prepared for war. Poor planning and lack of organization left planes sitting on the tarmac at airbases, allowing the Luftwaffe to destroy 4,000 Soviet planes within the first week. The disorganized Soviet defenses and technologically deficient aircraft were no match for the Luftwaffe.  \n \nIn 1942e major factors contributed to the resurrection of the Soviet Air Force. One aspect was the mostly successful evacuation of the aircraft industry and the lack of German attacks on this industry. Furthermore, the successful creation of a talented command staff and successful reorganization, which was supported by Stalin. The restructuring efforts included the transformation into air divisions, whereas each division consisted of one type of aircraft, which improved the logistics and command efficiency. Additionally, the use of on-board radios grew, which allowed better coordination with ground stations for warning and command-and-control. There were also tactical changes like the creation of special ace units and the use of free hunts with experienced pilots. The Soviet Air doctrine focused strongly on fighters in order to achieve air superiority, thus a considerable effort was spent to develop the fighter arm into an elite force.
Ivan Nikitovich Kozhedub

Ivan Nikitovich Kozhedub, born on June 8, was born in the village of Obrazhiyevka, a settlement in the Sumy region during the Russian Civil War. He graduated from the Shostka chemical technical school in early 1940 and joined the Soviet army in 1940. He graduated from the Chuguev Military Air School in 1941 at the start of the German invasion of the Soviet Union, but he was retained as an instructor. Kozhedub remained at the school for two years where he trained many young Soviet pilots. Feeling his talents would be better used in combat, he requested a transfer to an operational unit and in March 1943 was posted, as a Starshii Serzhant, to 240th IAP, one of the first units to receive the new Lavochkin La-5.  \n \nAfter his first military flight on 26 March 1943, he operated on the Voronezh Front and, in July over the Kursk battlefields. His first kill was a Junkers Ju 87 Stuka shot down during the Battle of Kursk on 6 July 1943. He claimed his 61st and 62nd victories - his final claims - over Berlin on 16 April 1945, making him the top scoring fighter pilot on the Allied side during World War II. He is one of the few pilots to have shot down a Messerschmitt Me 262 jet and was made a Hero of the Soviet Union on three occasions.
Skip Bombing

The first use of low-altitude bombing in WWII properly belongs to the British. On September 4, 1939, 15 British Bristol Blenheim bombers assaulted a group of German vessels near Wilhelmshaven, Germany. From an altitude of 100 feet, the aircraft crews dropped their bombs straight onto the decks of the ships - not skipped them up to or into the hulls. These first efforts failed to sink the ships. However, demonstrate the precision of a low-altitude attack. The British continued to use low-altitude techniques and eventually began to incorporate skip bombing into their tactics. \n \nAmerican skip bombing began on August 26, 1941, when General Henry 'Hap' Arnold, Chief of the Army Air Forces, heard details of a British skip bombing attack at an Allied conference in England. Upon his return from England, General Arnold charged developmental teams at Eglin Army Airfield, Florida with the task of creating an American version of skip bombing. After Pearl Harbor (December 1941), it was used prominently against Imperial Japanese Navy warships and transports by Major William Benn of the 63rd Squadron, 43rd Bomb Group, Fifth Air Force, United States Army Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific area theater during World War II.

Historically, on 21 August 1942, eighteen Germans made the ascent to the peak of Mount Elbrus, the highest point in Europe. Fourteen men were from the 1st Mtn Div and four were from the 4th Mtn Div. Oberfeldwebel Kümmerle planted the German battle flag, whilst the standards of both the 1st & 4th Mtn Divisions were planted alongside. \n \nOn February 1943, the Red Army was instructed to examine the abandoned camps on mount Elbrus and to replace the swastika with the flag of the Soviet Union. A group of ill-equipped soldiers lead by the legendary Alexander Gusev with nothing more than civil winter clothing, army boots and assault riffles but with a lot of patriotism climbed Elbrus and replaced the swastika with the flag of the Soviet Union.

During the first days of Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union, the Germans came unprepared to encounter Soviet T-34 medium tanks and KV heavy tanks. Although the Wehrmacht succeeded in most operations due to superior tactics, air support and supply, the lack of anti-tank weapons capable of successfully engaging these vehicles at range was becoming evident. An urgent need arose for a mobile and powerful enough anti-tank weapon than the already existing towed anti-tank guns or tank destroyers like the Panzerjäger I. Among a series of solutions, it was decided to use surplus light tanks, like the Panzer II, and captured vehicles, like the Lorraine Schlepper, as the basis for makeshift tank destroyers. The result was the Marder series, which were armed with either the new 7.5 cm Pak 40 anti-tank guns or captured Soviet 7.62 cm F-22 Model 1936 field guns, large numbers of which had been acquired early in the war. Its high profile and thin open-topped armor provided minimal protection to the crew. Nevertheless, the Marder II (and similar Marder III) provided a great increase in firepower over contemporary German tanks during 1942 and into 1943. \n(two brigades will be placed in your building quee, ready in 60 days, to simulate usage of capture equipment during Barbarossa)

The Battle of Bialystok-Minsk was a German strategic operation conducted by the Army Group Centre during penetration of the Soviet border region during the opening stage of Operation Barbarossa. Its goal, the encirclement of the Red Army forces around Minsk, was accomplished. The Soviet troops trapped in the gigantic pockets continued fighting, and concluding operations resulted in high German casualties. An estimated 250,000 Soviet troops escaped because of the lack of German infantry troops' motor transport that slowed the encirclement process. Most of them were later sent to penal battalions. There were 290,000 Soviet soldiers captured, and 1,500 guns along with 2,500 tanks were destroyed or captured. The quick advance east created the possibility for the Wehrmacht to advance rapidly towards the land bridge of Smolensk from which an attack on Moscow could be planned. It also created the impression in the OKW that the war against the Soviet Union was already won within days of its start.

The Battle of Smolensk was fought around the city of Smolensk between 10 July and 10 September 1941, about 400 km west of Moscow. The Wehrmacht had advanced 500 km  into the USSR in the 18 days after the invasion on 22 June 1941. Historically, the Germans were able to link up and close the pocket east of Smolensk on 27 July, trapping large portions of 16th, 19th, and 20th Armies. Under the leadership of 20th Army, Soviet troops managed to break out of the pocket in a determined effort a few days later, assisted by the Soviet offensive efforts along the Smolensk front line. In the end, about 300,000 men were taken prisoner when the encirclement was re-established and the pocket eliminated. A total of 1,348 - 3,273 tanks and guns along with 903 aircrafts were either destroyed or captured by the German Army.

The First Battle of Kiev resulted in a very large encirclement of Soviet troops in the vicinity of Kiev and is considered the largest encirclement in the history of warfare (by number of troops). The operation ran from 7 August to 26 September 1941 and encircled much of the Southwestern Front of the Red Army (Mikhail Kirponos), although small groups of Red Army troops managed to escape the cauldron, days after the German pincers met east of the city, including the headquarters of Marshal Semyon Budyonny, Marshal Semyon Timoshenko and Commissar Nikita Khrushchev. Kirponos was trapped behind German lines and killed while trying to break out. \n \n The battle was an unprecedented defeat for the Red Army, exceeding even the Battle of Białystok-Minsk of June-July 1941. The encirclement trapped 452,700 soldiers, 2,642 guns and mortars and 64 tanks, of which scarcely 15,000 escaped from the encirclement by 2 October. The Southwestern Front suffered 700,544 casualties, including 616,304 killed, captured or missing during the battle. The 5th, 37th, 26th, 21st and the 38th armies, consisting of 43 divisions, were almost annihilated and the 40th Army suffered many losses. Like the Western Front before it, the Southwestern Front had to be recreated almost from scratch.
